top_comment.text:
Expert spicy food eater here. I dunno why, but the scoville scale is often 
misleading, lemme tell you why.

I eat habanero hot sauce everyday, and I'm just fine, I don't feel much of 
a heat. I also tried a ghost pepper sauce they produce in Seattle and I 
could handle it perfectly. 

The only sauce that makes me want to throw myself into a pit is a sauce 
I've only seen available in a taco stand in Mexico City. This taco stand 
only opens at night (it starts serving tacos like at 10 pm and stops early 
in next day's morning); there are many taco stands such as this one that 
only open at night because the sauce they serve is so spicy that drunk 
people carve it so that their drunkness waters down. However, this 
particular taco stand has the hottest sauce. 

Aaaaaand, guess what?? The pepper they use for that sauce is chile de árbol 
(the 4th pepper they tried, I think), which is significantly less spicy 
than habanero. Not even the ghost pepper sauce I tried was this spicy. 

This is why I say that the Scoville scale is misleading. I'd like to see 
these two guys trying the aforementioned sauce and jump out the window.﻿
top_comment.author: Efraim Hernández

top_comment.text:
I just thought I would interject something. The capsaicin, which is the 
chemical in the pepper that makes it spicy, is actually stored in the veins 
of the pepper. Not the seeds. Also, the reason water doesn't help, is 
because capsaicin is an oil based chemical and water and oil do not mix. 
Little science for you.﻿
